content.text: A cylindrical disc is shown in Fig. 1.1
The disc has diameter \(28 \text{mm}\) and thickness \(12 \text{mm}\)
The material of the disc has density \(6.8 \times 10^{3} \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\)
Calculate, to two significant figures, the weight of the disc
weight =   .........  N

SI base units of \(K\)    .........

Give reasons for your answers

average velocity =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)

Calculate the average force acting on the car between \(t = 1.5 \text{s}\) and \(t = 4.0 \text{s}\)
A car of mass \(1500\mathrm{kg}\) travels along a straight horizontal road
The variation with time \(t\) of the displacement \(\mathbf{x}\) of the car is shown in Fig. 3.1
Distinguish between gravitational potential energy and elastic potential energy
Calculate, for the ball,
1. the initial kinetic energy,
kinetic energy =   .........  J
2. the maximum height reached
maximum height =   .........  m
The ball takes time \(t\) to reach maximum height. For time \(\frac{t}{2}\) after the ball has been thrown, calculate the ratio

content.blockMath: \[\frac{\text{potential energy of ball}}{\text{kinetic energy of ball}}.\]

content.text: State and explain the effect of air resistance on the time taken for the ball to reach maximum height
A ball of mass \(65\mathrm{g}\) is thrown vertically upwards from ground level with a speed of \(16\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). Air resistance is negligible

A battery connected in series with a resistor R of resistance 5.0 \(\Omega\) is shown in Fig. 6.1
The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery is 9.0V and the internal resistance is \(r\)
The potential difference (p.d.) across the battery terminals is 6.9V
On Fig. 7.1, draw six field lines to represent the electric field between the metal plates.
Calculate the electric field strength \(E\) between the plates
Two horizontal metal plates are connected to a power supply, as shown in Fig. 7.1
The separation of the plates is \(40\mathrm{mm}\)
The switch S is then closed so that a potential difference of \(1.2\mathrm{kV}\) is applied across the plates

Sphere A has charge \(- e\) and sphere B has charge \(+ e\), where \(e\) is the charge of a proton. The length AB is \(15 \text{mm}\). The rod is supported at its centre C so that the rod is horizontal and in equilibrium
The switch S is then closed so that the potential difference of \(1.2 \text{kV}\) is applied across the plates
There is a force acting on A due to the electric field between the plates
Show that this force is \(4.8 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\)
The insulating rod joining A and B is fixed in the position shown in Fig. 7.2
Calculate the torque of the couple acting on the rod
The insulating rod is now released so that it is free to rotate about C
State and explain the position of the rod when it comes to rest
The switch S is opened and the plates lose their charge. Two very small metal spheres A and B joined by an insulating rod are placed between the metal plates as shown in Fig. 7.2
